characters: CHASE ALL THE WAY UNTIL THE GAS STATION.
OBVIOUSLY, THIS WILL ALL DEPEND ON LOCATION AND STORY
DEATH TOLL CLIMBS TO NINETEEN. AGENT BEGINS INDEFINITE
-WAKES UP SUDDENLY IN HIS LIVING ROOM
-CAMPBELL WAKES UP INT. WAREHOUSE, LIVE/WORK LOFT
BOARDS. THE GENERAL POINT IS TO INCLUDE CAMPBELL IN THE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The low moon illuminates the quiet lake. The beautiful Chicago skyline glimmers in the distance. All is still until- From behind the skyline a WHIRRING mass of rotor blades appears gradually closing in our position. Soon, three F.B.I. helicopters BOOM past and continue on, sweeping low across the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen police vehicles scream through the streets of Chicago. Two motorcycle cops have blocked cross traffic and the convoy races through the light. When the convoy passes, the two motorcycles race back past the convoy, ready to block the next intersection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spirited CUBAN MUSIC fills this expensively decorated and trendy loft. Windows compromise one whole wall of the room offering a stunning view over the lake. DAVID ALLEN GRIFFIN (35, handsome; despite his apparent good mood, he has an eerie presence) suddenly dances into frame. He whirls and steps unselfconsciously to the feisty rhythms, holding a heavy black automatic pistol in one hand. Mid-twirl he turns and addresses someone off camera.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: Ooh. This song is faboo. Do you feel that? The rhythm? It's alive.  He dances, humming along with the song and occasionally turning to look playfully at his image in a large three- pane mirror as if he were flirting with an unseen partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopter moves low and fast over a desolate expanse of water. Behind the COMMAND PILOT, several FEDERAL AGENTS gaze soberly toward their destination. ON THE COMMAND PILOT: His profile taut in the florescent glow of his monitor. The lights of Chicago disappear in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griffin continues to dance for a moment before winding his motion down gracefully as the song fades. In the absence of music we hear for the first time the sound of a WOMAN in the room quietly crying and whimpering nearby. The next SONG suddenly jumps to life on the CD player and Griffin launches into another dance number, again humming along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOVERING FOR A MOMENT high above the glittering water, they PLUNGE toward their target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police vans and patrol cars screech to a lurching halt in front of the warehouse. The rear doors of the vans burst open and one after another, COPS in riot gear pour out onto the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the rooftop of a nearby building, there is a tremendous build-up of police personnel. A S.W.A.T. COMMANDER motions for his men to clear the way as the three helicopters rise over the rooftop's ledge and land in unison. The federal agents duck the churning blade as they rush into the nearest stairwell. Dozens of helmeted cops line the roof's ledge. VARIOUS ANGLES ON high-powered rifles, trained on the warehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AS a song ends, Griffin addresses someone off camera.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: I don't know how you can just sit there with music like this. Such a waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small army pours into the building through every ground floor entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A metal door crashes open as waves of S.W.A.T. officers storm the darkened basement. As they advance, their red- laser sights tracing a maze of pipes through the cavernous basement.

dialogues.speaker: S.W.A.T. OFFICER
dialogues.text: (into his headset) Basement's clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agent in charge, MIKE IBBY (44, African American) and several other AGENTS approach the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A team of S.W.A.T. officers thunder up the metal fire stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A second S.W.A.T. team races up a different stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another S.W.A.T. team kicks open a door to a loft, scaring the hell out of COUPLE watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SECOND S.W.A.T. Officer hustles three terrified PEOPLE down a dark hallway.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND S.W.A.T. OFFICER
dialogues.text: Let's go! Let's go! Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S.W.A.T. officers storm the hallway on the fifth floor gathering at a door. The LEAD OFFICER nods and two officers stand and ram the door down with a battering ram. FREEZE THE IMAGE. A voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's never that easy. You go through the door and they're never just sitting there waiting for you, a welcoming smile on their face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOEL CAMPBELL (late 30s, weary, scraggy, full beard, baggy chords, a baseball cap) sits across from his psychiatrist POLLY BEILMAN (37, attractive, poised).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best we can do is hope they fuck up and do what we can to be there when they do.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Do you blame yourself for the killings?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: No, I blame the asshole who did them. Polly almost cracks a smile.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. I don't blame myself for not catching him, if that's what you mean. This isn't a guy whose been in and out of an institution his whole life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black and white cruiser has pulled over an older model station wagon. TWO COPS walk up on either side of the car. As he approaches the driver, Cop #1 suddenly draws his weapon. Cop #2 follows his lead.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...whose brain finally pops and he slaughters five people then drives around in the family station wagon till a cop sees him run a red light. The DRIVER raises his hands. Blood covers his face and arms.

dialogues.speaker: BLOODY GUY
dialogues.text: Is there a problem, officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a man whose whole life is about killing. He studies it. He knows forensics. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMPBELL (CONT’D) He understands police procedure. He prepares methodically so as not to leave any evidence at the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHARON (attractive, 27) strolls through a local deli/market with a hand basket full of groceries.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He brings a kit with tools and props. Duct tape, hand cuffs, a weapon. Everything he'll need for control, pleasure and murder. Anonymous POV of Sharon picking through a stack of onions.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He may watch her for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon gets out of her parked car and walks, alone, down the mostly deserted street in a middle-class neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Learn her routine. When she comes home, when she goes to sleep. A car drives slowly down the street past her and pulls into a space. The lights go off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV from outside the window looking in: Sharon prepares herself breakfast in a very revealing outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the morning, before the sun comes up, he can walk right up next to her.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Why the morning?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Even though the sun's still down, nobody perceives it as night. Women that are very careful at one a.m., will walk around half naked four hours later. Polly makes a quick note on her notepad. Her expression suggests that it's a note to herself to take care in the mornings.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Finally, he’d pick a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again a CU of a man's feet walking down a long corridor. CU on man's hands as he first puts on a pair of latex gloves, slips pair of cotton gloves over them, and then picks the lock of an old doorknob.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He'd let himself into her apartment. The lock clicks open and he pushes the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon approaches her apartment door. She fumbles around in her purse for her keys for a long time. Aftera minute she gives up and starts to head back down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That night she'd get home, go about her business, unaware that he was in the house.  She gets a few steps away and suddenly stops in her tracks. She found the keys. She turns and lets herself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door swings open, spilling light from the hallway across the small living room. She closes the door behind her and for a few seconds the apartment is totally black. Her footsteps can be heard then BANG!

dialogues.speaker: YELP
dialogues.text: She clicks on a light and rubs her shin. She bumped the coffee table in the dark. She sets down her purse and keys and heads down the dark hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps into the bathroom and flips on the light.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She might spend her last moments alive in this world taking a piss or feeding her cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon pushes open her bedroom door and flips on the light and heads towards the closet, pulling her shirt off as she walks. Griffin stands behind the bedroom door, calmly. She doesn't see him. She opens the closet door and begins to rummage through her clothes. Griffin pushes the bedroom door closed with a just audible CLICK. Sharon slowly turns and sees Griffin standing inside the closed bedroom door. She yelps, covers herself with her hands and tries to run but there's nowhere to go. She runs headlong into her tiny closet, pulling down a bunch of her clothes, literally trying to climb the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon sits whimpering loudly on the sofa. She has duct tape across her mouth and her feet are bound together with her own stockings. Griffin stands nearby at a CD rack browsing through her CDs. He takes out a CD and puts it in.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: Oh. Here we go. Shall we dance? Ballroom dance music suddenly pours out of the stereo. He holds out his hand. Sharon sits, still totally immobilized with fear. She begins to whimper a little louder.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, don't play hard to get. This'1ll be fun! Shhhhhhh. Shhhhhhh. He dances over to her and tries to pick her up but she wails and her body goes limp, slipping out of his arms.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shhhhhhh.  Shhhhhhh. (suddenly enraged) I said SHUT UP! She does.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: The torture would last hours. Unimaginable terror. Campbell notices that Polly looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to disturb you, I just-

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: (snapping out of it) No, no. Don't be sorry. This is important for you, it's just difficult sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, tell me about it. (points to clock) You're off the hook anyway. She looks at the clock on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: (still composing herself) Yeah. I guess so. Okay, so I'll see you next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell lets himself into his apartment, a dark unfriendly place. Books and magazines fill every conceivable corner, making the place seem even smaller than it is. He tosses a hand-full of mail into a basket of similarly unopened mail. The camera lingers on an unopened FEDERAL EXPRESS envelope. He tosses his jacket carelessly on the couch and crosses the room to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell enters and washes his face, pulling his shirt tail out. He opens a drawer and pulls out several bottles of prescription medication, opens each one and shakes out a couple pills. He tosses them all into his mouth and takes a drink from the faucet, swallowing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell walks into the kitchen looking for food. All he can find as a browning apple which he grabs and heads back into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up his keys (which have a Swiss army knife on them) and a Victoria's Secret catalogue that came in the  mail and sits on the couch. He opens the knife and begins peeling the apple and opens the catalogue, obviously only half-interested in its contents. The apple skin comes off in one long, spiral piece. He sets it on the table and takes a bite of the apple. He loses interest in the catalogue all together and tosses it on the coffee table. He leans back and stares toward the window, lost in thought. TIME LAPSE - The light behind the window shade gradually fades. Campbell still stares at the window until long after dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griffin stands in front of the mirror covered in blood and sweat, exhausted from the ordeal of murder. As he methodically cleans himself up, he addresses himself in the mirror, though he seems to be talking to someone else, the way one might speak to a deceased loved one.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: Where did you go? I wonder what happened to you that night? Why was it so different from the other times? I don't know why you were there, how you got so close to me that night. He bends over and washes his face.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I remember clearly what I felt when I heard your footsteps falling behind me... Pride. For me it was our finest hour. I thought it would keep us together forever. I can still see the flames...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep black smoke pours from several broken windows. The orange flicker of fire light can be seen behind several other windows.  Campbell (younger) gun in hand, sprints down a dark deserted alley toward the house. Though he runs as hard as he can, in dreamlike fashion he doesn't seem to making very much progress.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Campbell running up the back staircase and into the back door, immediately ducking away from the rush of flames and heat. He covers his mouth with his arm and pushes into the back hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN'S hideous SCREAMS of agony and fear. Campbell pushes further down the crumbling hallway, dodging burning debris that falls around him. His progress is impeded by thick smoke that blurs what's happening. He can just make out the image of a woman sitting in a chair in a room at the end of the hallway. She SCREAMS again, a long piercing howl. The camera focuses in on a wall of flames until it fills the entire frame. Images of horrible prime scenes begin to appear superimposed over the flames: horribly mutilated bodies, pools of blood, bloody clothes, murder weapons. The scream continues throughout until-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bolts up right on the couch, covered in sweat, his face distorted with pain. His moves are frantic and jerky. He grips his hands over his eyes and stumbles towards the bathroom but can't keep his feet. HIS POV: the room blurs and the floor seems to buckles as he CRASHES onto the hard wood.  He writhes in agony, kicking the walls and pressing both hands against his temples as if to stem the pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finally gets it together enough to make it to the bathroom, frantically dumping out drawers and throwing open cabinets. Campbell slumps into the floor. HIS DISTORTED POV: as he paws at a pile of drugs and toiletries that lay sprawled across the floor. His hand finds a pharmaceutical carton and he tears it open with his teeth. He pulls the rubber protective tip from a small syringe and plunges into his thigh (which is badly marked and scarred from many similar occasions). He pulls out a second syringe and repeats the process. He drags himself the rest of the way into the bathroom and throws up violently into the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, it's night time. Campbell stirs awake. He's been on the floor the whole day. He stands up and washes his mouth out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell enters the kitchen and opens the refrigerator. Nothing. He slams it closed and checks the cupboard but the cupboard's dry. He closes it as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell walks out his front door and down the street toward a Chinese Restaurant across the street. He looks haggard. We follow from an ANONYMOUS POV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell sits in the middle of the mostly empty restaurant near the front window, eating his dinner with  chopsticks. He does not notice several police cruisers that pass the front of the restaurant with their lights on. Again someone watches from across the street. Campbell seems miserable and very much alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell steps out of the restaurant and is surprised by the sight of an active crime scene in front of his building. Campbell walks up and stands with a CROWD of onlookers. COPS and PARAMEDICS pass this way and that. After a moment, Campbell ducks the police tape and slips unnoticed into the front door of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell ducks another line of tape and into the hallway. LIEUTENANT HOLLIS MACKIE (33, Southern twang and a bad haircut) stands in the hallway talking to some COPS. He sees Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Hi. Welcome to my crime scene. Can help you or are you just looking?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (pointing at the stairwell) I just live here.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (stepping in his path) Did you not see the bright yellow tape that said 'Do Not Cross' on it? Campbell holds up his wallet, showing Hollis his ID.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (weary) Can I just go upstairs? I don't feel like arguing with you. Hollis looks at the ID for a moment then shouts down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emelda! Hollis calls her over with a quick nod.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Got a picture? EMELDA (a young Hispanic cop) hands it over. Hollis hands the picture of Sharon to Campbell. The photo (probably found in Sharon's apartment) is taken at her high school graduation.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know this woman?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Never seen her. What happened? She dead?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (suddenly very suspicious) We didn't say anything about a homicide... Mister... (looking at the ID) Campbell. Now why would you jump to that conclusion?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm just real insightful. You got half the block taped off and there's a dozen cops in my lobby. What conclusion should I jump to, that someone stole her stereo? Campbell heads toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Wait. Call me if you think of anything? Campbell turns back around. Hollis walks over and hands him a card. Campbell turns around and heads up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell sits on the bed watching the Home Shopping Network holding a half-glass of Jack Daniels. He looks miserable. CU on a man's hand holding a faux diamond necklace.

dialogues.speaker: TV SALESMAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from the TV) This cubic zirconium necklace is perfect for her birthday, anniversary, or Christmas present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downstairs, a PHOTOGRAPHER flashes shot after shots of Sharon. Off the last flash, the screen flashes entirely white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sweeping vista of Chicago in the first light of day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell eats cereal and rifles through an enormous pile of unopened mail. Bills, junk mail, nothing interesting. He gets to a Fed Ex envelope and tears it open and shakes out the contents. A single 8'x 10' black and white photo. CU a photograph of Sharon, last night's victim, sitting alone in a what appears to be a small restaurant - still alive. Campbell stands and quickly rummages through an enormous pile of unopened mail and unread newspapers and magazines near the front door, finally pushing the dumping a small table onto the floor. He finds what he's looking for: Another unopened Fed Ex envelope. He rips it open and another black and white photo slips out. It's a picture of a different woman driving alone in a her car. It's taken from a car moving alongside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE CUT: a cell phone RINGS just as Hollis swerves violently through traffic nearly killing himself and twenty others. He's in pursuit of a Honda Accord that just made a quick left. His police radio SQUABBLES almost as loud as the TIRES of his car. After he fishtails around the corner and down shifts, quickly gaining his lost ground on the Honda, he answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (surprisingly calm) Lieutenant Mackie. INTERCUT WITH CAMPBELL'S APARTMENT; Campbell jerks his head away from the receiver, startled by the SCREAMING tires, engine ROAR, and blaring SIRENS.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (loudly over the noise) This is Joel Campbell. We met last night.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (driving insanely) Campbell. Sure, sure. Our ex- F.B.I. friend from apartment 805. (answering the unasked question) We did some checking after you left last night. What can I do for you? Hollis almost runs down four PEDESTRIANS, locking up all four tires just long enough to miss them, then punching the gas again. He doesn't even flinch. Several police cruisers have joined the chase.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (truly perplexed) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (still totally calm) Some asshole just jacked a Honda two blocks from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, shit, do you need to call me back?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (wrenching the wheel) No, I'm fine. You got something for me?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (still very loud) When'd she die?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (still driving insanely) Monday night. Three days ago. Why?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Cause I know who did it.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: And how might you know that?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Because he mailed me a picture of her still alive. Got it three days ago. Monday morning.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (blown away, almost happy) No shit!? Several patrol cars suddenly cut off the Honda and it skids to a halt. Two Asian YOUTHS jump out and flee on foot.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Campbell, hold on a sec. Team Honda here's on the run. Hollis jumps out of his car and chases one of the kids, still holding his cell phone. After a short sprint, Hollis has closed the gap. He tackles the kid, dropping his cell phone, and the two of them skid along the dirty pavement. The phone slides ten feet away. A UNIFORM jumps on the kid and cuffs him. Hollis walks over and picks up the cell phone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back into the phone) Meet me at my office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis looks at a picture of Sharon (which is now ina plastic evidence bag). Campbell sits across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: You always open your mail four days after you get it? Campbell tosses Hollis the second picture (also in plastic).

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: No, sometimes it takes up to two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: I guess that answers any question we might of had whether the two cases were related. Oh, boy, my first serial.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Glad your having fun with this.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (laughing) Are you kidding? He's sending us pictures, Campbell! Call Bob Barker! It's a fucking game show.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (moving on) Strangled with piano wire? Victim was partially unclothed but the swabs all came back negative?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Exactly. No touchy, no feely. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: His last known alias is David Allen Griffin. We attribute at  least 11 homicides to him. I worked him for three and half years. In L.A. All I ever got was a cast on a pair of nine and half Nikes.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: In L.A.? What the hell's he doing in Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Killing people, looks like.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (holding up the picture) He ever come after you before?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: No, he's never sent pictures or contacted me directly before.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: So it's not necessarily the same guy?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Are you seri-? He sent mea picture and then killed her in my own fucking building. (snapping in his face) Try to keep the pace, man, this is serious.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (whistles) Three and half and a pair of Nikes, huh? (Campbell stands) Bureau's involved now, I assume?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Safe assumption. Campbell stands up.

dialogues.speaker: F.B.I. HEADQUARTERS
dialogues.text: Campbell walks down a long corridor led by MIKE IBBY (44, African American).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got off the phone with your ex-boss in L.A. He sends his best. Campbell doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: IBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He told me you were a good agent. Great instincts. Told me you know this animal better than anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: It's not my job anymore.

dialogues.speaker: IBBY
dialogues.text: He and I both think maybe it should be. We're setting up a task force with Chicago P.D. I'd like you to lead it from our end. We can reactivate-

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (stopping in his tracks) The field office in L.A. has the relevant files. I can't tell you anything that's not in them. Have a nice day. Campbell turns to walk away just as AGENT MITCH CASPER (young, almost boyish-looking) exits his office.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: (ignoring Campbell, to Ibby) We got several sets of prints from the Fed-Ex envelope. Campbell half turns around as he walks out.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: You can run ‘em but you're going to get the delivery boy, the receptionist, three guys from the warehouse, Santa Clause, everyone but him. You're going to have to do much better than that.  Ibby and Mitch look at Campbell, vaguely annoyed at his comment. Campbell turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snap! 1HR. PHOTO is a small store in a very busy indoor shopping mall, though the store itself is deserted. ELLIE (24, mousy), sits behind the counter making faces into a Sony Digital Video camera that broadcasts her image onto several monitors in the store. She sticks out her tongue; blows a bubble; makes a fish face, etc., clearly bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of shoppers cross this way and that, no one paying attention to the others. After a moment, we see Griffin, making his way toward Snap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griffin walks in and catches Ellie making faces. She smiles apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: That's quite alright. You looked adorable. Ellie blushes. Griffin walks up to a display and pulls a roll of Kodak film off the rack.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This new Kodak film stock, it says it's for exterior sunshine, but how's it handle Fluorescents? Ellie shrugs and throws up her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing at herself) I'm sorry, I have no idea what you're talking about. (shrugs again) I just work here. Griffin smiles at her and looks up at the ceiling: Fluorescent lighting.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: Do you guys process here, as well?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. One hour. Griffin tears open the film and picks up a display camera on the counter. He opens the back of the camera.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Sure, but what are you doing? Once the film is loaded, he raises the camera and points it at Ellie.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: I'm going to test it out. He clicks a picture of her. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll shoot a few pictures and you can process them for me. He clicks another picture of her. She laughs again, this time making a face at his camera. He clicks another. She's clearly enjoying the attention. He clicks several more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell, looking more and more haggard and distraught each time we see him, sits across from Polly in her posh office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a young man, do you plan to live on disability your whole life? Campbell holds out his arms and surveys himself, implicitly inviting her to do the same.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: I take 150 milligrams of seconal so I can sleep two and half hours a night. You want lives in my hands? Acebutolol and benazepril for blood pressure, I self inject migrainol and imitrex for migrain -

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: You're simply afraid-

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: I go places and forget why I'm there. I miss exits on the freeway. You want lives in my hands? I'm lucky to find my way home from the grocery store.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: You're simply afraid that you'll make another bad judgment that you won't forgive yourself for and you're avoid-

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (almost shouting) Absolutely! I'm avoiding that situation. No, I don't trust myself. Would you?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Then why do you come here? What's the point of these sessions? Are you trying to get well so you can get out on the golf course next spring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the next picture that arrives were of your daughter would you really want me to be the one looking for her? Would you really?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: (thinks for a beat) Yes. Yes I would. He stands up, unwilling to listen, and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't walk out now. This is exactly what you want. You have to admit that. Right now is the time. He slams the door in her face. She throws her note down in exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell sits watching footage of the crime scene on the late news. A reporter stands outside Ellie's house.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: The harrowing search came to a tragic end at about 9:20 p.m. when police discovered the body of Ellie Buchner at her Wicker Park home. Campbell punches the remote and the screen goes to black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell (younger, clean-shaven) walks up to the front porch of the house, careful not to be seen or heard. He peers under the blinds into a window. Through the thick leaded glass his POV is distorted. A figure moves in the living room. Several candles provide the only light in the room. Campbell pulls away and looks through another window, trying to get a better idea of what's happening.  From the second window he can see a woman bound and gagged. His breath quickens. He stands and kicks the front door in and-

dialogues.speaker: -WAKES UP SUDDENLY IN HIS LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Campbell sits up in his EZ chair, apparently having fallen asleep in the chair. It's daylight. He looks at the clock: 6:40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell walks down the sidewalk. P OV from someone following him a few feet behind. Campbell heads toward the front door of Polly's building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell crosses the polished granite floor of the expansive lobby and heads toward a bank of elevators. He chooses an elevator and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell punches his floor and leans against the wall. The door starts to close but at the last second opens again. Griffin steps in. Griffin punches the same floor as Campbell and the two ride in silence, not looking at each other. Campbell yawns. He looks rather haggard froma night of little sleep.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: Long night? Campbell nods. They ride up the rest of the way in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell steps into the hallway and Griffin steps out behind him. Campbell walks down the hallway, Griffin right behind him. He comes to a fork in the hallway and takes the left corridor.  Campbell follows. Griffin grins.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: Are you following me?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: I could ask you the same question. They share a small laugh and keep heading down the hallway soon arriving at Polly's door. Campbell slows and for instant it seems as if Griffin is going to stop too but he doesn't. He walks down the hall and Campbell ducks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell sits fidgeting in a chair across from Polly.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: I don't have time to be here but I appreciate what you said last week and didn't want you to think that I was walking away for the wrong reason.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: (she smiles) How have the headaches been?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: About the same.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Are you sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Some.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: How's work?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: It's great. I'm getting so popular, I've got murders requesting me by name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk about that. How are you making sense of this man following you here? Is ita vendetta?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (after a moment) I don't think vengeance has anything to do with it. There's a story, a ritual, in this, that he follows. Over the years, I became part of the story. It didn't make sense without me.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: In other words, he missed you.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Odd isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: I don't know. Did you miss him?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Well the description you just gave could apply to you, don't you think? Campbell is taken aback, unsure if he's ready to concede her this point. After a moment, his phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Excuse me. (into the phone) Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Got a match on the prints.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: I'll be right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell, Ibby, and Mitch sit in Campbell's office. Campbell reads from a file folder. Mitch looks wrecked. He's been here all night.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Norton Inglert. Vagrancy 1987. Vagrancy 1991. I.Q. estimated at below eight zero which makes him officially... not Griffin.

dialogues.speaker: IBBY
dialogues.text: Let's pick him up. You got a last known address?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Yeah, a by-the-hour-motel where he stayed eight years ago. Mitch get some sleep. Diana, you wanna ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell drives; Diana sits in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: The report came in from the camera shop. Lots of prints everywhere. The lab's running them to see if anything interesting turns up.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: It won't. He’d have been more careful than that. If he touched anything he’d have wiped it clean. Anyone see anything?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Nope. There was one fun bit, though. He filled out the photo-order with your name and address. Campbell cringes. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A disaffected clerk sits smoking behind the counter watching TV. CU on the TV as a day-time TALKSHOW HOST stands in front three GUESTS.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: There's five million people in this city! How can nobody have known this poor girl? How can this happen in the age of communication with emails, fax, phones-

dialogues.speaker: GUEST
dialogues.text: (pompous ) On the contrary, Maggie. It could have only have happened in this age. These tools of communication allow us to function as a society with less and less real human interaction. Campbell and Diana enter. The clerk doesn't even look up.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (showing a photo) Surprise me. Tell me, that Norton Inglert still stays here.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL CLERK
dialogues.text: (glance at the photo) Norton Inglert. Nope.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Would fifty bucks make him more likely to be here?

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL CLERK
dialogues.text: For fifty bucks I'd tell you Elvis' got a room by the pool and gives a free concert Thursday nights but that don't make it so. He turns back to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't agree more with Don. A hundred years ago, she would have been living in a single structure with her parents, brothers and sisters, cousins... Back to the TV. Campbell and Diana split.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: That's true, but I tell you what, it still irks me! (then pointing to the camera and smiling) Next, after this, we take your calls! We have hundreds of calls waiting and we'll see how Many we can get through!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell drives with Diana. His phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: What up 'C'? I found your retard.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: I'll meet you. Off the record, though. Just me and you. My guy's still undercover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell and Hollis stand on the dock with JACK FRAY (35, long hair, leather jacket).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So check it out. Last year we were getting close to the Russians. We nailed this asshole with a pocket of rocks and next thing we know he's a first class U.S. citizen. He gives up everyone he knows and makes up a few others for effect.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So most of them are worthless. We haven't even used them. Don't want to blow our own cover. But one of the names was a retard name of Norton they used as a drug mule.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: You got an address?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Not on the mule, but here's the rat. He hands Campbell a folder. He snaps it back.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You understand if this gets on the street we could lose lives? Campbell nods and takes the folder.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (reading) Stanislaw Mikahailovich. Possession. On Probation. Current address 859 West Washington.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Be careful, boys. He's a pussy. But he's a crazy pussy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell and Hollis step quietly from Campbell's car. The guys gaze across and up the street at a dark house with six-foot weeds in the yard and plywood over the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell and Hollis stalk quietly up to the front door. Campbell kneels to the left of the door, Hollis to the right. Campbell nods. Hollis bangs loudly on the front door. Hollis bangs again and leans back down away from the door.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (strong Russian accent) Who is it!?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Police! Open the door. (then as an aside to Campbell) Oh, sorry, Campbell. (shouting again) The F.B.I. is here too!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What you want?!

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: We're selling tickets to the Policeman's ball, douche bag. BLAM! BLAM! Campbell hits the porch when the door partially disintegrates as Stanislaw blasts two rounds through it. Hollis shrugs, stands up, and kicks the rest of the door in. Campbell makes a circle with his index finger, and slinks off the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pitch black. Hollis walks inside. BLAM! BLAM! The house lights up as someone unloads from down the hallway. Hollis doesn't even bother to duck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, asshole. Stop shooting. You can't even see me. How you're going shoot me? BLAM! The house flashes brightly again. Hollis walks down the hall, right towards the gunman.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shouting) Cut that shit out or I'm gonna shoot your ass. BLAM! Click. The sound of the hammer against loud footsteps can be heard rustling around the back of the house as the guy makes a run for it. Hollis runs through the rest of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis bursts out the back door just in time to see Stanislaw fly end-over-end as Campbell clunks him in the shin with a two-by-four. Hollis laughs heartily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell and Hollis interrogate Stanislaw who sits cuffed to a dinette chair in the middle of his living room. He sits in his boxer shorts. Hollis holds a fat copy of the Chicago white pages.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (casually) 500 North Carmine Avenue? Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: STANISLAW
dialogues.text: (heavy accent) You can't just come in here when you want to whenever! I have immunity! So fuck you! Hollis flips the book closed and thumps Stanislaw back and forth across the face with it a couple times -- not too hard, just enough to shut him up and get his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Standi- Stamis-, uh, listen, Coleslaw, we know the address is in here. (he opens the book again) And we're going to stay right here until you tell it to us. 5789 Rountree Drive? That it?

dialogues.speaker: STANISLAW
dialogues.text: Fuck off. Thump. Thump. Thump. Stanislaw's eyes dart around as the intimidation sets in. He looks like an unwilling participant in a Three Stooges skit. Thump. Thump.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (again looking at the book) 413 Broadway? Stanislaw hesitates. Thump. Thump. Thump. Campbell laughs, then suddenly picks Stanislaw up and shoves him against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: "From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs.' You understand that? Isn't that Kremlin rhetoric? Now you see, we need some information and you have the ability to give it to us.

dialogues.speaker: STANISLAW
dialogues.text: (giving up) Okay, okay. Alright, here it is, alright? He used to work at a fucking laundry mat, alright?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: STANISLAW
dialogues.text: On East Elm near the lake, alright? Near the fucking lake. Whatta I give a shit about some fucking retard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun rises over the cityscape.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LAUNDROMAT, ALLEY WAY
dialogues.text: Two unmarked cop cars pull up to the rear entrance of the laundromat. There's a truck parked at the back door and its cargo door and the back door to the laundromat are open. Plainclothes COPS step out of the car and loiter nearby, waiting. Campbell and Hollis walk casually up to the door. As they approach, the OWNER walks out from the back carrying an enormous canvas bag of laundry on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LAUNDROMAT OWNER
dialogues.text: (dropping the bag) Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (showing badge) Special Agent Campbell, F.B.I. This is Lieutenant Mackie, Chicago Police.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (showing a picture) Does Norton Inglert still work here?

dialogues.speaker: LAUNDROMAT OWNER
dialogues.text: Yes he does and he's a good kid. I don't know what-

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Do you have an address?

dialogues.speaker: LAUNDROMAT OWNER
dialogues.text: Of course, but he's a good kid. Whatever it is you guys-

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: The address? Now. The owner turns to walk inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis stands talking on his car radio. Campbell stands within earshot. Hollis reads from a small note pad.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: 4240 Crossbend Avenue. Surveil only! Do not go inside! Surveil only! Nobody inside until I get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polly sits at her desk talking to a patient.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Usually, Mr. Abraham, I do an introductory session where we explore what you hope to get out of therapy. If we both feel like I'm the person to provide that for you then we'll decide on a schedule together. Cut back to reveal that it is Griffin that she's talking to. She sets the tape recorder between them. Griffin takes note of the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like to record my sessions. But if you prefer for me not to-

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: Is that something that you do with all of your patients?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: With most. Do you prefer that I don't?

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: No. I'd rather you not.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Okay.... that's fine.  She puts the recorder away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell arrives and jumps out. The place is surrounded with COPS and Norton is already in custody, sitting handcuffed and very frightened in the back seat of a cruiser. The car is about to pull away. Campbell runs toward it, flagging it down.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! What the fu- The DETECTIVE IN CHARGE jumps in the way.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE IN CHARGE
dialogues.text: (getting in his face) Who the hell are you? Campbell shoves the detective out of his way and he slips, falling to one knee. He pops back up angrily and shoves Campbell. They eye each other dangerously.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Back the fuck up! We're on TV here people. He points to a camera crew and reporter that have just arrived, camera rolling.

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE IN CHARGE
dialogues.text: (dismissively) I had to make a decision, Lieutenant, he was on the move. I had to make a decision.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Bullshit. The only decision you made was whether or not to be a hero in the biggest case this city's seen in decades and we know which way you came out on that, you fucking prick.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (still holding them apart) Campbell, let's go to the district office, you can talk to him there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing, cocky) There's not much left to talk about. Franklin found a shirt with blood on the sleeves and the fucking loony couldn't confess fast enough. You should of seen it, Hollis, he's blabbing away and I'm in his face trying to read his Mirandas fast enough to use the Goddamn confession. Campbell and Hollis turn and walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griffin continues his session with Polly.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: You said you felt like you might need help. In what area?

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. What kind of help do you provide?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Ahhhhhhh. Well, I work with patients on many different issues-

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: I don't like when you say "issues'. It just bothers me. Don't do that. (she's taken aback by this) Do you think some of your patients might pay to come see you because you're very pretty?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: (trying to regain control) Mr. Abraham let's try to keep focused on you rather than me... It is clear that she does not like her newest patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell sits across from Norton, who is quite scared.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Norton, I know that you're afraid, but I'm trying to help you.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: (growing more upset) Okay. I'm sorry. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell me what you're sorry for? Did you hurt her?

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: I looked at her. Norton grows very shy.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Norton, did she see you look at her?

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: How'd the blood get on your sleeves, Norton? Did you touch her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis and several OTHERS are watching from behind the glass.

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Did you hurt her when you touched her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Did she scream or tell you to stop touching her?

dialogues.speaker: NORTON
dialogues.text: No. She was asleep.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (to the mirror) Impressive work, guys. Norton, listen to me. You're not going to be in trouble anymore. Norton doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Norton, did you see someone else hurt her? Did you see someone else at the apartment? After a long moment, Norton nods his head 'yes'. Campbell sits up excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, Norton, I want to play a little game with you now, okay? We're going to try to drawa picture of the man you saw. Just then JACKSON (the D.A.) and MENDEL (a defense attorney) burst into the interrogation room with Hollis and two UNIFORMS at their heels.

dialogues.speaker: MENDEL
dialogues.text: This interrogation is over! Campbell stands. Norton cowers away from the commotion.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: MENDEL
dialogues.text: I'm his attorney.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: It wasn't an interrogation to begin with. Hollis, we gotta get a sketch artist in here. He saw the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No we don't 'gotta' do anything. (to the uniforms) Escort this man back to his cell. The cops grab Norton by the arms and lift him out his chair. No,

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: no, no. He may have seen the guy kill her. He'sa peeping Tom, that's all. He must of touched her body. For Godsakes, I'm trying to help him here. Oh,

dialogues.speaker: MENDEL
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) we're sure you are, Agent Campbell. And we appreciate that. Campbell looks to Hollis who shrugs. Norton has already been led out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell and Hollis stand outside the district office.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Let me talk to his lawyer. I know a guy who knows a guy that can put some pressure.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Get me a fucking sketch of this guy and we can nail him! Do not let this disappear. Campbell turns and walks away, disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young girl heavy boots, stamping her

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: (JESSICA) wearing a very dirty army jacket, and other punk-rock accessories stands feet against the cold on a busy sidewalk bumming change. She approaches several PASSERSBY all of whom ignore her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, spare some change for a room? It's cold tonight.... Sir... Ma'am I didn't sell enough girl scout cookies and... Dad! Don't you recognize me. It's me! Her hopes deflate. Another PASSERBY approaches.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir, spare some change? Cutting to her POV reveals that Griffin is the passerby. He doesn't answer but he stops.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Spare some change, mister?

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: (disarmingly direct) What are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: (very girlish) Spanging. Spare changing.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: Don't you have a job or anything?

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. And I can buy the fuckin station wagons full of screaming kids? Fuck that very much. The revolution's coming. You wait.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: Well, I very much doubt that. But I do admire your ideals. Somehow when you get older they all seem to just go away.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Yeah, whatever. So can you spare 'some change or what?

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: Only if you dance with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing, surprised) Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: I'm serious. He holds his hand out to her. She smiles and blushes, a very young girl again.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: There's no music.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: I'll hum for us. He begins humming out the rhythm. She takes his arms and he leads her through a few steps.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: (giggling) You better give me some money.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: I will. She stops suddenly, laughing too hard to continue.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: I can't. I can't. Just give me some money.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: (laughing with her) You can. C'mon. He starts humming again. She takes his hands with a laugh and they dance again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A form moves across the moonlit window. A moment later a flashlight pops on. POV, lit by the flashlight, as a file cabinet drawer slides open. As a hand rifles through the files. He gets to 'Joel Campbell' and pulls the file. He opens another drawer and pulls Campbell's tapes, carefully replacing the plastic covers so that from a casual glimpse that don't appear to be missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a dark room, the only light from a photocopier repeatedly coping pages, the light eerily creating an intermittent silhouette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide shot of the cityscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell sits behind his desk looking through the crime scene photos and other evidence. After a few seconds, one of the overhead florescent lights begins to flicker. Immediately, Campbell covers both eyes and cowers from the light.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (calling out) Somebody give me a hand! Can somebody turn out the light in here for a minute!? No answer. Campbell stands up, his eyes still closed.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (losing patience) Can someone grab this light for me!? After another couple seconds, Campbell loses it. He jerks the keyboard of his commuter free from the desk and hurls it overhead into the bank of fluorescents, sending glass and the keyboard crashing back down with a great clatter. Hearing the commotion, Diana runs into his office.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keyboard in hand) Sorry to disturb. Flickering lights trigger migraines faster than anything else. He tosses the keyboard onto the desk casually. She shakes her head and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Great to have you around, Campbell. Adds great color. Campbell's secretary pops her head in his office behind Diana.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL'S SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Agent Campbell? This came for you a few minutes ago. He turns to look at her. She holds up a Fed-ex envelope.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL'S SECRETARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (clueless) Do you want it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell, Ibby, Mitch, and Diana stand in front of another gallery of posters - extreme closeups of every inch of the frame. Almost everything is out of focus except for her face.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: These are just blown straight up. They're trying to pull some of this shit into better focus.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: This is shot with a long lens to get the shallow depth of field which is going to make it hard. He's trying to give us as little context as possible.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: It's working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least this one's outside. Where is she sitting? Let's start there. Get someone from the city in here. Let's see if they recognize the sidewalk or the parking meter or anything else.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: I'm on it. Campbell looks closely at a shot of a tattoo on her forearm.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Mitch, put a picture in every tattoo parlor in Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, Hollis addresses the PRESS. This time, however, there are more than a hundred REPORTERS and PHOTOGRAPHERS.

dialogues.speaker: AGGRESSIVE REPORTER
dialogues.text: Would you say that the arrival of the photo calls into question the arrest the department has-

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (on edge) -the arrest was based on very strong evidence and our department stands by it. If it turns out that the killer is still at large then we obviously will release the suspect as quickly as is feasible. Several reporters blurt questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The row of young agents settle into their chairs in front of bank of phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The daytime ANCHORWOMAN addresses the camera. Jessica's picture is on the screen above her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORWOMAN
dialogues.text: Police released this photograph just moments ago. This woman appears to be the next target in this horrifying game of cat and mouse. MONTAGE. SHOTS OF VARIOUS CITIZENS WATCHING THE NEWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica sits in the doorway of a condemned building chatting with a young KID with a skateboard about her age.

dialogues.speaker: SKATER
dialogues.text: Watch, watch check it out. The skater tries a trick on his skateboard, busting his ass with great flare. Jessica laughs hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: SKATER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sweetly) What are you laughing at? That's the trick. You know how long it took me to learn that for you? Jessica laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TECH sits in front of a twenty-inch computer screen on which one section of the photo has been blown up. As Campbell and company watch, the photo slowly comes into clearer focus. RACHEL (from city planning) looks over his shoulder. She points to the base of a street lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like she's sitting next to an old cast-iron street lamp.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Which puts her where? She turns and pushes open a grid-map of the city and takes a magic-marker and draws a fairly large rectangle.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Somewhere in the old town area. A lot of territory. Campbell looks disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a stack of newspapers next to a sidewalk newsstand. Jessica's face is on the cover. Pull back and track down the street a few dozen feet and reveal Jessica panhandling in her usual spot. No one even looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Dad! It's me, don't you recognize me? I had the plastic surg- (the guy keeps walking) -Hey, man, can I bum a smoke? (a second guy shakes his head) Then how bout a few bucks for a pack? (he keeps walking) Hi! Spare some change, I'm-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griffin sits in a plastic lawn chair wearing a bathing suit, headphones, and sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from the walkman) In other words, he missed you. Just like you missed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well the description you just gave could apply to you, don't you think? Griffin smiles and pushes rewind then play again. POLLY (0.S.) (CONT’D) -description you just gave could apply to you, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WANDA (57) has a hammer in one hand, nails in her mouth, and a large glass framed inspirational poster in her hand which she's attempting to hang by herself. ' On the TV behind her we HEAR a CNN special report.

dialogues.speaker: CNN REPORTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It appears that the murders may be linked to a serial killer in the Los Angeles area. CU of the TV screen. A photo of Jessica fills the screen. CNN REPORTER (0.S.)(CONT’D) At this point, the woman police are calling "Jane Two" has not yet been located and all those involved are very concerned about her well being. Wanda turns around and sees Jessica on the television and drops the poster, sending glass shattering across the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell peruses the photo one last time with the magnifying glass. He stops and holds his view for a beat on a black mesh trash receptor of the same black and chrome design as the chair Jessica sits in. Ibby rushes into the office. Everyone looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got Jane’s mother on the phone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three F.B.I. vehicles (including Campbell's car) race out of the gates and onto the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vehicles race toward Wanda's two-story Victorian home. The house is surrounded by local police cars. Campbell, Mitch, and Diana run toward the front door. Wanda's hysterical screaming can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell takes in the scene: three COPS, several NEIGHBORS, and WANDA'S SISTER surround Wanda, who sobs hysterically, and mumbles a PRAYER.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (taking over the scene) Mrs. Stendhal, I'm Agent Joel Campbell with the F.B.I. Wanda continues to sob. WANDA’S SISTER She doesn't know anything! Can't you see what kinda shape she's in-

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: I can see that but if we don't find her daughter she's- WANDA’S SISTER (almost screaming) She doesn't know anything!

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: What do you mean she doesn’t know anything?  WANDA’S SISTER Jessica ran away almost two years ago. We don't know where she is.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (takes a breath) Who are you? WANDA’S SISTER I’m the girl's aunt. Wanda's sister.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (to the cops) Hey! Clear everyone else out of the house. Let's get some quiet in here right now. (to the sister) Help me with her for a few minutes and then we'll leave her alone. Deal? Sit with her. Campbell turns to Mitch. CAMPBELL (CONT’D) Start with outreach programs for runaways. Get them her picture. Where do teen runaways hang out?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Broadway and Belmont area.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Get everyone you can down there with her picture. Start with CD shops, convenience stores, video arcades, fast food joints, anywhere else kids would go and then fan out from there. He turns back to Wanda, who still sobs. He her. CAMPBELL (CONT’D) Mrs. Stendhal? I know that no one wants us to find Jessica more than you do, but in order for that to happen, you're going to have to help us out. kneels with  She just continues to sob. He sighs. CAMPBELL (CONT’D) (to the sister) Okay, listen, spend a few minutes with her. Calm her down. Can I take a look at Jessica's room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica's face is plastered across 40 television screens at Circuit City. The nighttime ANCHORMAN'S VOICE booms through the store.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHORMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jessica Stendhal. That is this young woman's name. She is sixteen years old and thought to be living somewhere in Chicago. Police have located the young woman's mother but unfortunately they have not located Jessica. INT. JESSICA’S ROOM - LATER Campbell and Diana stand somberly in Jessica's room, rifling through Jessica's belongings, which Wanda has left untouched. The walls are covered with posters, magazine cutouts, etc. Campbell notes a 'Tony Hawk' skateboard poster as well as posters for 'The Offspring', 'Hole', and others. He notes a light blue Fender Stratocaster electric guitar. On the table are several issues of 'Thrasher Magazine' (a skateboard magazine).

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Make a couple calls for me. Get a picture to every skateboard shop and park and the guitar shops close to Belmont and Broadway. I'm going to look for her letters and-

dialogues.speaker: WANDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There aren’t any. Campbell and Diana turn to see Wanda and her sister in  the doorway. Wanda's calmed somewhat. WANDA (CONT’D) She never wrote anybody. She did call two or three times after she disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Did she say where she was calling from?

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: She wouldn't tell us anything. She always wanted to talk to the damn dog. She'd make me put the phone up to it and she'd coo and make baby-talk.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Can you remember anything at all about those calls? Anything might help.

dialogues.speaker: WANDA
dialogues.text: What does it matter? It's all lies anyway. She's on drugs. We did what we could. She begins to sob again. Her sister pats her shoulder. WANDA (CONT’D) She said all kinds of things. I never knew what to believe. She had a new boyfriend. A lawyer. Yeah right! She called once to say she had a job at the Starbucks. Campbell looks at a clock on the wall. 5:10. INT. CAMPBELL'S CAR/HOLLIS’ OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER Campbell races through traffic. The sun is just beginning to disappear behind the horizon. He talks to Hollis on the cell-phone.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Bad news. She does not work nor has she ever worked for Starbucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit! That can't be right. Look at the picture, Hollis. She's sitting at a coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (looking at the photo) I don't know. Just looks like a chair to me. Could be anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Look at the trash can next to her Hollis looks at the wire mesh trash can. CAMPBELL (CONT’D) See what's in it? White paper cups. She's sitting ata fucking Starbucks.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: (standing) I'll see what I can do. Hollis opens the map of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG COP shows the STAFF behind the counter a picture of Jessica.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: Her name is Jessica Stendhal. Are you sure you haven't seen her? The kids all shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another COP shows a picture of Jessica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another COP talks to a CLERK behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally, man. She comes in here all the time. The cop reaches for his radio and lifts it to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MATCH CUT to Hollis lifting his phone to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Positive ID. The Starbucks on Lincoln and Wisconsin.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Meet you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's now quite dark as dozens of uniformed POLICEMEN roam the area, passing out hundreds of black and white fliers with Jessica's picture on them. Most people don't even want to take the fliers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the interior walls have been torn down on the top floor of this abandoned, turn-of-the century office tower leaving a wide-open space that makes for a great moonlit playground for Jessica and her skater friend. He stands on his skateboard holding her hands as she runs, pulling him in and out of the support beams slalom style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell and Hollis question the clerk. Mitch stands nearby.

dialogues.speaker: STARBUCKS CLERK
dialogues.text: Yeah, I told the other dudes she comes in but she doesn't work here. I let her use the bathroom, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea how we can find her? Where she lives?

dialogues.speaker: STARBUCKS CLERK
dialogues.text: Dude, she lives on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell walks out into the night air, unsure what his next move should be. He watches a couple uniformed COPS passing out fliers with Jessica's picture on them. Several PEOPLE don't even look at the fliers, simply shaking their heads as they pass. A BUSINESSMAN brushes off one of the COPS with a shrug. Campbell loses it, running wildly up to the cop and grabbing his fliers and chasing down the businessman, and spinning him around roughly.

dialogues.speaker: HAVE YOU SEEN THIS GIRL
dialogues.text: The businessman is shaken up by Campbell's assault but after a moment he manages to look at the photo.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: No. I’m sorry- Campbell pushes him away and turns to the next nearest PASSERBY and again scares them into paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: You! Look at this girl's face! Do you know her? Have you seen her?

dialogues.speaker: PASSERBY
dialogues.text: No, I--

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Look at her before you answer!

dialogues.speaker: PASSERBY
dialogues.text: (looking) No. I don’t know her.  Campbell spins and aggressively approaches another PASSERBY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanda sits in her sister's arms, crying quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica and the skater sit huddled together around a fire that they've built from scraps of cardboard and sheet rock. A small cheap jambox plays a BAUHAUS song.

dialogues.speaker: SKATER
dialogues.text: I have to go. I'm sorry. I'm so late.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Can I go with you? Can I sneak in your room?

dialogues.speaker: SKATER
dialogues.text: We can't, Jess, last time we got caught my dad went ballistic. Don't be sad, Jessie. I gotta split. He stands up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to the building, the skater ducks a chain link fence and steps into the alley. He turns on the sidewalk and heads toward Campbell who, fifty feet away, continues to flag down passing PEDESTRIANS. The kid almost skates right by Campbell who talks to a YOUNG WOMAN, but Campbell hears the sound of wheels against the concrete and spins around. His gaze lands on the kid's board.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: (holding up his hand) Stop, wait! The skater clocks Campbell for a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I didn’t do anything.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: I didn't say you did. (he holds up picture) Do you know this girl? She's about your- The surprise on his face is evident.

dialogues.speaker: SKATER
dialogues.text: Fuck you, cop. I don't know shit.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Listen to me- The kid suddenly makes a break for it, darting across traffic and almost getting squashed. BRAKES squeal and horns BLARE. Hollis looks up and catches a glimpse of Campbell chasing the kid right toward where he is standing. The kid sees Hollis and veers into an alley. Hollis drops his fliers and runs after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica lies quietly, alone in front of the dying fire, huddled in a dirty sleeping bag to ward off the cold. Reverse to what would be Jessica's POV if she turned around and we see a figure silhouetted against the Chicago skyline.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHICAGO ALLEY WAY
dialogues.text: The skater tries to out sprint Hollis but Hollis catches him, tackling him roughly onto the dirty concrete. The skater comes up swinging, kicking, biting, scratching and screaming. Hollis tries to restrain him without hurting him.

dialogues.speaker: SKATER
dialogues.text: Fucking cop! Fuck you! I didn't do shit! Fuck you! Let go.  Campbell catches up, looks around to make sure no one's looking, and then open-hand slaps the shit out of the kid.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: If you don't help me, right now, a man is going to wrap piano wire around her neck so viciously it will almost sever her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica sits by the fire. Her face tightens as she senses someone behind her but she doesn't turn around. The figure approaches the firelight revealing that it is in fact Griffin. Though she is clearly nervous, she tries not to let it show.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: Hi. What are you listening to?

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: Bauhaus.

dialogues.speaker: GRIFFIN
dialogues.text: (singing) Bela Logosi's dead. Bela Logosi's dead.

dialogues.speaker: JESSICA
dialogues.text: No way. You know it? Here, let me turn it up. She sits up and adjusts the volume, casually picking up the jambox in the process and then SMACKING it into Griffin's face. She stands up and sprints through the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The skater now leads Hollis and Campbell on a full-run back to the abandoned building. As they cross the main street near the Starbucks, Hollis radios for back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griffin now runs through the darkness in the direction Jessica had gone. She makes it across the top floor and to the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pitch black and only shapes can be seen. HEAVY BREATHING and FOOTSTEPS fill the empty space. After making it down two flights of stairs, she comes to a closed door (which, knowing the building, she had expected) and has to run across another abandoned floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike the top floor, however, the kids haven't kicked down all the interior walls of this floor. Griffin closes in right behind her. She knows she can't out run him so she makes the dangerous decision to duck into one of the old offices, initiating a deadly game of hide and seek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The skater, Campbell, and Hollis sprint through traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessica has managed to crawl from office space to office space, apparently unseen by Griffin. Several times she has to make the horrifying leap from behind one wall to another exposing herself briefly in the moonlight as she inches her way toward the other stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downstairs, the skater leads Campbell and Hollis under the chain-link fence and into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell, Hollis, and the kid run up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: SKATER
dialogues.text: (breathing hard) She sleeps on the top floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell, Hollis and the kid burst through the stairwell and onto the seventh floor (where we last saw Jessica). A shadow passes the light ahead. Campbell stops short and puts a hand on the kid's chest. Hollis immediately pulls the boy back into the stairwell. Campbell moves quickly, gun drawn, down the main corridor toward the direction he saw the shadow. He fires FIVE SHOTS instinctively as Griffin leaps from the darkness and into the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the stairwell, Griffin slams his weight into a steel door (leading down to the next floor) but the door won't budge. After a couple tries he turns and heads up the stairs. Griffin runs up the stairs. Campbell pounds the metal stairs below him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griffin reaches the top floor and crosses as fast as he can toward another stairwell. Campbell kicks the door open and takes FOUR MORE SHOTS at his figure. Again, Griffin goes untouched. He makes it to the other stairwell and heads toward the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of other cops pour into the building. Two police helicopters hover over the building, spotlights sweeping the brick and broken windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griffin runs onto the roof. Shortly thereafter, the police helicopters have him in their spotlights. Campbell bursts onto the roof and runs full-sprint toward Griffin, shooting insanely without breaking stride. Griffin spots a smaller office building below; he sprints and leaps from the roof over an alley way, tumbling as he lands two stories below. Campbell follows him dangerously across the alley. At the other end of the building, Griffin jumps again, this time to an even lower building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide shot of storefronts as Griffin hurdles from one rooftop to the next as he finally eludes the searchlights and disappears between buildings, Campbell right on his heels

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up Griffin mid-air a second before he lands feet first on the exploding windshield of a truck. He tumbles off and steals down the alley. Campbell jumps across the alleyway to a nearby fire escape and quickly jumps from level to level, until he reaches bottom level. He jumps into the alley and chases Griffin.

dialogues.speaker: CHASE ALL THE WAY UNTIL THE GAS STATION.
